title: The differences between Meta, MetaPlus, Meta LL, and Meta LF?
content:
What are they?

I asked a few friends and co-workers but no one really knew for sure. A few responses I received were:

1] They are made by different type foundries but essentially the same. (As I recall they were designed by Erik Spiekermann?)

2] Some are better used as body text and others for signage?

3] Some are used as Light and Bold sets?

Can someone out there help distinquish between them? Thank you.
author: Erik

comments.content:
[This article by Yves on FontShop's FontFeed](http://web.archive.org/web/20100504081729/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontfeed/archives/2005/10/ff_metamorphosi.cfm) should give you a headstart.

LF stands for lining figures, or tabular figures, i.e. when you arrange them underneath each other in a table, they will line up. Don't know what LL means; Light Lining (figures)??

Thanks for linking to that article, Vincent. That should clarify the MetaPlus vs. Meta.

A correction: Lining and Tabular figures are not the same thing. [Lining Figures](http://web.archive.org/web/20100504081729/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Lining%2520Figures) actually means the numbers line up horizontally. You could call them "all caps" or "titling" figures. Lining figs can be proportionally spaced. TF stands for [Tabular Figures](http://web.archive.org/web/20100504081729/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Tabular%2520Figures) which means they all have same width for tabluar setting.

I have never heard of Meta LL.
\*sigh\* I'm sure I'll get the figures right some day... Thanks for the correction, Stephen.
